awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The role of compensation in the evolution of ornaments
awd_abstract_narration:
Evolution is responsible for many bizarre and showy physical characteristics (i.e. ornaments) in males, but how they remain reliable indicators of male quality remains controversial. Current hypotheses indicate that ornaments are costly to their bearers, however studies testing for decreased locomotor performance or decreased survival or reproductive success (i.e. Darwinian fitness) as a result of ornaments have been inconclusive. For large ornaments, selection should favor evolution of traits and behavior that offset costs of ornaments, thus concealing their true costs. Stalk-eyed flies provide an ideal model system to test for costs and tradeoffs related to male ornamentation due to their exaggerated head morphology, with eyes displaced at the end of long stalks. These flies exhibit considerable variation in muscle and wing size, compensatory traits that may offset the inertial effects of eye stalks on flight performance. This research incorporates biomechanical and flight performance experiments to characterize compensatory ability in relation to ornament size, and determine how the interaction of ornaments and compensatory traits impact flies' ability to evade predators and reproduce. The proposed research has the potential to significantly revise our understanding of how exaggerated traits evolve and also improve our understanding of biomechanical compensation for ornaments and inform bio-inspired engineering efforts such as miniature drones. This research will provide technical training and professional development to a post-doctoral scholar, a technician and graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach efforts at both campuses will provide STEM education to elementary students and training to K-12 educators.

This research employs a novel theoretical and empirical approach to assess the costs of ornaments by considering how compensatory ability in relation to relative ornament size affects the interaction between viability and fecundity. Three distinct avenues of research will be integrated to achieve this goal. First, using species of stalk-eye flies within the family Diopsidae, patterns of correlated evolution between eye stalks and compensatory traits will reveal the macroevolutionary consequences of selection and test the hypothesis that relative ornament size will be positively correlated with the relative size of compensatory traits within and across species. Second, a series of flight performance, maneuverability and predator-avoidance experiments will test the hypothesis that relative compensatory ability predicts viability costs. Finally, a series of mesocosm experiments, where predation and competition interact, will test whether investment in ornamentation versus investment in compensatory traits offers different means to the same fitness end in stalk-eyed flies; the mesocosm experiments will assess the reproductive consequences of viability costs associated with under-compensating for large ornamentation compared to the viability advantages associated with over-compensating for small ornamentation.

por.por_cntn:
Sexual selection in biology is responsible for many bizarre and elaborate male ‘ornaments’, for example antlers in deer and elk and plumage in birds. One of the most elusive questions in animal behavior is how ornaments used during mate choice and rival assessment remain reliable over evolutionary time. The prevailing hypothesis is that ornaments are costly to their bearers (i.e., ‘handicaps’). However, most studies on costs of ornaments are equivocal or contradictory. We sought to build on recent work showing that natural selection favors compensatory traits that offset costs associated with ornaments. Stalk-eyed flies (Fig 1) provide an ideal model system to test for costs and tradeoffs related to male ornamentation because all species in this extraordinary family display exaggerated head morphology, with eyes displaced at the end of long stalks. The exaggerated head-morphology of stalk-eyed flies should impose costs on flight performance, particularly through increased mass and moment of inertia, negatively influencing maneuverability and flight performance. This project sought to characterize the patterns of correlated evolution between eye stalks and traits that could compensate for the costs associated with eye stalks. We focused on traits such as thorax, abdomen, and wing size that are important determinants of flight performance. Flies with relatively small thoraces and wings, relative to the span of their eye stalks, would be ‘under-compensating’ for the flight performance costs associated with bearing long eye stalks; whereas flies with relatively large thoraces and wings would be ‘over-compensating’, and therefore possess an advantage during flight-related behaviors. However, because adult stalk-eyed flies reach sexual maturity over the course of 4 weeks, facilitated by the growth of reproductive tissues, it was also necessary to investigate how these compensatory relationships change across age.  

Age matters! As flies mature, they develop flight muscles and reproductive organs, which can also have effects on flight performance. We found a significant increase in body mass across age in adult female and male stalk-eyed flies. Overall, body mass increased quickly during the first week, then gradually increased over the following 7 weeks through maturity. All flies increased abdominal mass across age, consistent with our expectation for investment into reproductive tissues associated with sexual maturation. However, thorax mass also increased with age, which contributed to the maintenance and increase in the thorax-to-body mass ratio. Maximal flight performance was associated with thorax mass and increased with age even though flies became heavier, as the investment into the thorax compensated for the overall increase in body mass across age. Older flies -flies with greater thorax mass- were able to produce greater wingbeat frequency and wing velocity, which increased their maximal flight performance. Similarly, investment into the reproductive tissues of the abdomen during sexual maturation is compensated by investment into the thorax to maintain and/or improve flight performance as flies become heavier with age. Although flies with longer eye spans were larger, maximal flight was independent of eye span, presumably because younger flies had not yet accumulated sufficient flight muscle. Thus, flight performance appears associated with morphological compensation, specifically the growth of the thorax and flight musculature which facilitates the improvement in wing velocity. We showed that negative effects of flight performance were most prominent during early stages of development. By adulthood traits that compensate for the ornaments fully developed, suggests that selection of ornaments may be strongest early in the life.

Such age-related variation in muscle is not well-documented in adult insects, as most developmental studies focus on changes across juvenile stages and regard the adult stage as a terminus of development. Nonetheless, stalk-eyed flies’ increase in thorax mass across age was due to increased muscle mass. To test this idea, we clipped the wings of flies shortly after emerging from their cocoons to prevent them from flying as they matured. Flies with clipped wings developed less thorax muscle than flies which were allowed to fly, demonstrating a ‘training effect’ that accompanies the underlying developmental mechanisms that regulate the growth of thoracic muscle tissue. Abdomen growth reflects the expected resource investment into reproductive tissues. Interestingly, flies which were allowed to fly developed greater abdomen tissue mass than flies that were restricted from flight, demonstrating a complicated relationship between flight performance and between sexual maturity.

This project has provided opportunities for research participation, training in laboratory skills, development of analytical skills, research stipends, and training and opportunities in science communication for undergraduate and graduate students, including members of underrepresented groups.  We worked with local high school teachers to develop and published three Data Nuggets for use in high schools nationwide. Data Nuggets are free classroom activities. When using Data Nuggets students are provided with the details of authentic science research projects, and then get to work through an activity that gives them practice looking for patterns and developing explanations about natural phenomena using the scientific data from the study.
